title: 108_hr2692
content: The Act titled "United States Fire Administration Authorization Act of 2003" appoints the Administrator of the United States Fire Administration as per the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974. It also addresses the National Residential Fire Sprinkler Strategy. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to include a new subsection (b) for the National Residential Fire Sprinkler Strategy. This strategy aims to promote the installation of residential fire sprinklers, provide support to stakeholders, focus on high-risk residences, and prioritize occupants at high risk to fire hazards. The National Residential Fire Sprinkler Strategy focuses on promoting residential fire sprinkler installation, supporting stakeholders, and prioritizing high-risk residences with occupants at risk to fire hazards, such as senior citizens and persons with disabilities. It also emphasizes localized fire suppression in high-risk areas of residences. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to include support for maritime firefighting and updates to the Firefighter Assistance Grants Program, including grant-writing assistance for applicants. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to authorize appropriations for fiscal years 2004-2006 and provide courses and training assistance for firefighters. Additionally, new firefighting technology is emphasized. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to develop new measurement techniques and testing methodologies for evaluating firefighting technologies. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is being amended to evaluate new firefighting technologies, such as personal protection equipment, advance warning devices for extreme hazards, enhanced vision equipment, victim and firefighter locating devices, incident command information tools, virtual reality training methods, and robotics for remote operations. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is being amended to evaluate new firefighting technologies, including robotics and remote-controlled devices, to support the development of new voluntary consensus standards for firefighting technologies. The Administrator will require new equipment purchased through the assistance program to meet or exceed applicable voluntary consensus standards. The Administrator may waive the requirement for specific standards if voluntary consensus standards are met. Applicants must justify purchasing equipment that does not meet standards. The Administrator will determine waivers based on practicality. The Administrator may waive specific standards if voluntary consensus standards are met. Applicants must justify equipment purchases not meeting standards. Applicants applying for a grant under certain terms may include a second grant request in the application for consideration by the Administrator. The Administrator may waive standards if voluntary consensus standards are met. Applicants can include a secondary grant request in their application for consideration if the primary request is not approved due to equipment not meeting standards. Authorization of appropriations for new technology development is also provided. SEC. 9. COORDINATION OF RESPONSE TO NATIONAL EMERGENCY. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for establishing mutual aid systems for national emergencies, providing technical assistance and training to State and local fire service officials. This includes threat assessment, equipment deployment strategies, and collecting asset information for regional deployment. The Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to establish mutual aid systems for national emergencies and provide technical assistance to State and local fire service officials. The Administrator will develop model mutual aid plans for intrastate and interstate assistance. Within 90 days, a report on the strategic needs for deployment of volunteers and emergency response personnel will be submitted to relevant committees. The Firefighters' Safety Study Act (15 U.S.C. 2223e) mandates a national credentialing system for firefighters during national emergencies. The Director of FEMA must update the Federal Response Plan within 180 days to include plans for responding to terrorist attacks, especially in urban areas, and submit a report to relevant congressional committees. SEC. 10. TRAINING. Section 7(d)(1) of the Federal Fire Prevention and Control Act of 1974 is amended to include strategies for building collapse rescue, technology use in response to fires and national emergencies, tactics for dealing with terrorist-caused catastrophes, familiarity with FEMA's Federal Response Plan, and leadership skills. The National Fire Academy focuses on leadership, strategic skills, technology application, and terrorism response integration. The Superintendent may consult with other agencies for curriculum development, and coordination is done to avoid program duplication. The Administrator of the United States Fire Administration coordinates training with other Federal agencies to prevent duplication of courses for fire service personnel and establish a mechanism to eliminate redundant training programs.
